text: Jesus replied, “You unbelieving and perverted generation! How long must I be with you? How long must I put up with you? Bring him here to me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus rebuked the demon and it came out of him, and the boy was healed that very hour.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the disciples came to Jesus privately and asked, “Why couldn’t we drive it out?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He told them, “Because of your lack of faith. I tell all of you with certainty, if you have faith like a grain of mustard seed, you can say to this mountain, ‘Move from here to there,’ and it will move, and nothing will be impossible for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But this kind does not come out except by prayer and fasting.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While they were gathering together in Galilee, Jesus told them, “The Son of Man is going to be betrayed into human hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will kill him, but he will be raised on the third day.” Then they were filled with grief.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came to Capernaum, the collectors of the temple tax came up to Peter and asked, “Your teacher pays the temple tax, doesn’t he?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He answered, “Yes.”
When Peter went home, Jesus spoke to him first and asked him, “What do you think, Simon? From whom do kings on the earth collect tolls or tributes? From their own subjects, or from foreigners?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“From foreigners,” he replied.
So Jesus told him, “In that case, the subjects are exempt.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, so that we don’t offend them, go to the sea and throw in a hook. Take the first fish that comes up, open its mouth, and you will find a coin. Take it and give it to them for me and you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time the disciples came to Jesus and asked, “Who, then, is the greatest in the kingdom from heaven?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Calling a little child forward, he had him stand among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “I tell all of you with certainty, unless you change and become like little children, you will never get into the kingdom from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, whoever humbles himself as this little child is the greatest in the kingdom from heaven,
speaker: Narrator

text: and whoever receives a little child like this in my name receives me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “If anyone causes one of these little ones who believe in me to sin, it would be better for him if a large millstone were hung around his neck and he were drowned at the bottom of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: How terrible it will be for the world due to its temptations to sin! Temptations to sin are bound to happen, but how terrible it will be for that person who causes someone to sin!
speaker: Narrator

text: “So if your hand or your foot causes you to sin, cut it off and throw it away. It is better for you to enter life injured or crippled than to have two hands or two feet and be thrown into eternal fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if your eye causes you to sin, tear it out and throw it away. It is better for you to enter life with one eye than to have two eyes and be thrown into hell fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: “See to it that you do not despise one of these little ones, because I tell you, their angels in heaven always have access to my Father in heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Son of Man came to save the lost.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “What do you think? If a man has 100 sheep and one of them strays, he leaves the 99 in the hills and goes to look for the one that has strayed, doesn’t he?
speaker: Narrator

text: If he finds it, I tell all of you with certainty that he rejoices over it more than over the 99 that haven’t strayed.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way, it is not the will of your Father in heaven that one of these little ones should be lost.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “If your brother sins against you, go and confront him while the two of you are alone. If he listens to you, you have won back your brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if he doesn’t listen, take one or two others with you so that ‘every word may be confirmed by the testimony of two or three witnesses.’
speaker: Narrator

text: If, however, he ignores them, tell it to the congregation. If he also ignores the congregation, regard him as an unbeliever and a tax collector.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I tell all of you with certainty, whatever you prohibit on earth will have been prohibited in heaven, and whatever you permit on earth will have been permitted in heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Furthermore, I tell all of you with certainty that if two of you agree on earth about anything you request, it will be done for you by my Father in heaven,
speaker: Narrator

text: because where two or three have come together in my name, I am there among them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Peter came up and asked him, “Lord, how many times may my brother sin against me and I have to forgive him? Seven times?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus told him, “I tell you, not just seven times, but 77 times!
speaker: Narrator

text: “That is why the kingdom from heaven may be compared to a king who wanted to settle accounts with his servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he had begun to settle the accounts, a person who owed him 10,000 talents was brought to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because he couldn’t pay, his master ordered him, his wife, his children, and everything that he owned to be sold so that payment could be made.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the servant fell down and bowed low before him, saying, ‘Be patient with me, and I will repay you everything!’
speaker: Narrator

text: The master of that servant had compassion and released him, canceling his debt.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But when that servant went away, he found one of his fellow servants who owed him a hundred denarii. He grabbed him, seized him by the throat, and said, ‘Pay what you owe!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then his fellow servant fell down and began begging him, ‘Be patient with me and I will repay you!’
speaker: Narrator

text: But he refused and had him thrown into prison until he could repay the debt.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When his fellow servants saw what had happened, they were very disturbed and went and reported to their master everything that had occurred.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then his master sent for him and told him, ‘You evil servant! I canceled that entire debt for you because you begged me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shouldn’t you have had mercy on your fellow servant, just as I had mercy on you?’
speaker: Narrator

text: In anger his master handed him over to the jailers until he could repay the entire debt.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is how my heavenly Father will treat each one of you unless you forgive your brother from your hearts.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus had finished saying these things, he left Galilee and went to the territory of Judea on the other side of the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Large crowds followed him, and he healed them there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some Pharisees came to him in order to test him. They asked, “Is it lawful for a man to divorce his wife for any reason?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He answered them, “Haven’t you read that the one who made them at the beginning ‘made them male and female’
speaker: Narrator

text: and said, ‘That is why a man will leave his father and mother and be united with his wife, and the two will become one flesh’?
speaker: Narrator

text: So they are no longer two, but one flesh. Therefore, what God has joined together, man must never separate.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They asked him, “Why, then, did Moses order us ‘to give a certificate of divorce and divorce her’?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He told them, “It was because of your hardness of heart that Moses allowed you to divorce your wives. But from the beginning it was not this way.
speaker: Narrator

text: I tell you that whoever divorces his wife, except for sexual immorality, and marries another woman commits adultery.”
speaker: Narrator

text: His disciples asked him, “If that is the relationship of a man with his wife, it’s not worth getting married!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Not everyone can accept this saying,” he replied, “except those to whom celibacy has been granted,
speaker: Narrator

text: because some men are celibate from birth, while some are celibate because they have been made that way by others. Still others are celibate because they have made themselves that way for the sake of the kingdom from heaven. Let anyone accept this who can.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then some little children were brought to him so that he might lay his hands on them and pray. But the disciples rebuked those who brought them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus, however, said, “Let the little children come to me, and stop keeping them away, because the kingdom from heaven belongs to people like these.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he had laid his hands on them, he went on from there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just then a man came up to Jesus. “Teacher,” he asked, “what good deed should I do to have eternal life?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus asked him, “Why ask me about what is good? There is only one who is good. If you want to get into that life, you must keep the commandments.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The young man asked him, “Which ones?”
Jesus said, “‘You must not murder, you must not commit adultery, you must not steal, you must not give false testimony,
speaker: Narrator

text: honor your father and mother,’ and, ‘you must love your neighbor as yourself.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The young man told him, “I have kept all of these. What do I still lack?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus told him, “If you want to be perfect, go and sell what you own and give the money to the destitute, and you will have treasure in heaven. Then come back and follow me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the young man heard this statement he went away sad, because he had many possessions.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus told his disciples, “I tell all of you with certainty, it will be hard for a rich person to get into the kingdom from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Again I tell you, it is easier for a camel to squeeze through the eye of a needle than for a rich person to get into the kingdom of God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the disciples heard this, they were completely astonished. “Who, then, can be saved?” they asked.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus looked at them intently and said, “For humans this is impossible, but for God all things are possible.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Look!” Peter replied. “We have left everything and followed you. So what will we get?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus told them, “I tell all of you with certainty, when the Son of Man sits on his glorious throne in the renewed creation, you who have followed me will also sit on twelve thrones, governing the twelve tribes of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: In fact, everyone who has left his homes, brothers, sisters, father, mother, children, or fields because of my name will receive a hundred times as much and will inherit eternal life.
speaker: Narrator

text: But many who are first will be last, and the last will be first.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “The kingdom from heaven is like a landowner who went out early in the morning to hire workers for his vineyard.
speaker: Narrator

text: After agreeing to pay the workers one denarius a day, he sent them into his vineyard.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he went out about nine o’clock, he saw others standing in the marketplace without work.
speaker: Narrator

text: He told them, ‘You go into the vineyard, too, and I will pay you whatever is right.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So off they went. He went out again about noon and about three o’clock and did the same thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: About five o’clock he went out and found some others standing around. He asked them, ‘Why are you standing here all day long without work?’
speaker: Narrator

text: They told him, ‘Because no one has hired us.’ He told them, ‘You go into the vineyard as well.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “When evening came, the owner of the vineyard told his manager, ‘Call the workers and give them their wages, beginning with the last and ending with the first.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who were hired at five o’clock came, and each received a denarius.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When the first came, they thought they would receive more, but each received a denarius as well.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they received it, they began to complain to the landowner,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘These last fellows worked only one hour, but you paid them the same as us, and we’ve been working all day, enduring the scorching heat!’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But he told one of them, ‘Friend, I’m not treating you unfairly. You did agree with me for a denarius, didn’t you?
speaker: Narrator

text: Take what is yours and go. I want to give this last man as much as I gave you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am allowed to do what I want with my own money, am I not? Or are you envious because I’m generous?’
speaker: Narrator

text: “In the same way, the last will be first, and the first will be last, because many are called, but few are chosen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus was going up to Jerusalem, he took the twelve disciples aside and told them as they were walking along,
speaker: Narrator

text: “See, we are going up to Jerusalem, and the Son of Man will be handed over to the high priests and scribes, and they will condemn him to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they will hand him over to unbelievers to be mocked, whipped, and crucified, but on the third day he will be raised.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the mother of Zebedee’s sons came to Jesus with her sons. She bowed down in front of him to ask him for a favor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He asked her, “What do you want?”
She told him, “Promise that in your kingdom these two sons of mine will sit on your right and on your left.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jesus replied, “You don’t realize what you’re asking. Can you drink from the cup that I’m going to drink from?”
They told him, “We can.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He told them, “You will indeed drink from my cup. But it’s not up to me to grant you a seat at my right hand or at my left. These positions have already been prepared for others by my Father.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the ten heard this, they became furious with the two brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jesus called the disciples and said, “You know that the rulers of the unbelievers lord it over them and their superiors act like tyrants over them.
speaker: Narrator

text: That’s not the way it should be among you. Instead, whoever wants to be great among you must be your servant,
speaker: Narrator

text: and whoever wants to be first among you must be your slave.
speaker: Narrator

text: That’s the way it is with the Son of Man. He did not come to be served, but to serve and to give his life as a ransom for many people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As they were leaving Jericho, a large crowd followed Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: When two blind men who were sitting by the roadside heard that Jesus was passing by, they shouted, “Have mercy on us, Lord, Son of David!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the crowd told them harshly to be silent, they shouted even louder, “Have mercy on us, Lord, Son of David!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus stopped and called them, saying, “What do you want me to do for you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They told him, “Lord, we want to be able to see!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus, deeply moved with compassion, touched their eyes, and at once they could see again. So they followed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came near Jerusalem and had reached Bethphage on the Mount of Olives, Jesus sent two disciples on ahead and
speaker: Narrator

text: told them, “Go into the village ahead of you. At once you will find a donkey tied up and a colt with it. Untie them, and bring them to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: If anyone says anything to you, tell him, ‘The Lord needs them,’ and that person will send them at once.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now this happened to fulfill what had been spoken through the prophet when he said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Tell the daughter of Zion,
    ‘Look, your king is coming to you!
He is humble and mounted on a donkey,
    even on a colt of a donkey.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the disciples went and did as Jesus had directed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They brought the donkey and the colt and put their coats on them, and he sat upon them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Many people in the crowd spread their own coats on the road, while others began cutting down branches from the trees and spreading them on the road.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Both the crowds that went ahead of him and those that followed him kept shouting,
“Hosanna to the Son of David!
How blessed is the one who comes
    in the name of the Lord!
Hosanna in the highest heaven!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he came into Jerusalem, the whole city was trembling with excitement. The people were asking, “Who is this?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The crowds kept saying, “This is the prophet Jesus, the man from Nazareth in Galilee.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus went into the Temple, threw out everyone who was selling and buying in the Temple, and overturned the moneychangers’ tables and the chairs of those who sold doves.
speaker: Narrator

text: He told them, “It is written, ‘My house is to be called a house of prayer,’ but you are turning it into a hideout for bandits!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Blind and lame people came to him in the Temple, and he healed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the high priests and the scribes saw the amazing things that he had done and the children shouting in the Temple, “Hosanna to the Son of David,” they became furious
speaker: Narrator

text:
and asked him, “Do you hear what these people are saying?”
Jesus told them, “Yes! Haven’t you ever read, ‘From the mouths of infants and nursing babies you have created praise’?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he left them and went out of the city to Bethany and spent the night there.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning, as Jesus was returning to the city, he became hungry.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seeing a fig tree by the roadside, he went up to it but found nothing on it except leaves. He told it, “May fruit never come from you again!” And immediately the fig tree dried up.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the disciples saw this, they were amazed. “How did the fig tree dry up so quickly?” they asked.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus answered them, “I tell all of you with certainty, if you have faith and do not doubt, not only will you be able to do what has been done to the fig tree, but you will also say to this mountain, ‘Be removed and thrown into the sea,’ and it will happen.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will receive whatever you ask for in prayer, if you believe.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus went into the Temple. While he was teaching, the high priests and the elders of the people came to him and asked, “By what authority are you doing these things, and who gave you this authority?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus answered them, “I, too, will ask you one question. If you answer it for me, I will also tell you by what authority I am doing these things.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Where did John’s authority to baptize come from? From heaven or from humans?”
They began discussing this among themselves: “If we say, ‘From heaven,’ he will ask us, ‘Then why didn’t you believe him?’
speaker: Narrator

text: But if we say, ‘From humans,’ we are afraid of the crowd, because everyone regards John as a prophet.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So they told Jesus, “We don’t know.”
He in turn told them, “Then I won’t tell you by what authority I am doing these things.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “But what do you think? A man had two sons. He went to the first and said, ‘Son, go and work in the vineyard today.’
speaker: Narrator

text: His son replied, ‘I don’t want to,’ but later he changed his mind and went.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the father went to the other son and told him the same thing. He replied, ‘I will, sir,’ but he didn’t go.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Which of the two did the father’s will?”
They answered, “The first one.”
Jesus told them, “I tell all of you with certainty, tax collectors and prostitutes will get into God’s kingdom ahead of you!
speaker: Narrator

text: John came to you living a righteous life, and you didn’t believe him, but the tax collectors and prostitutes did. But even when you saw that, you didn’t change your minds at last and believe him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Listen to another parable. There was a landowner who planted a vineyard, put a wall around it, dug a wine press in it, and built a watchtower. Then he leased it to tenant farmers and went abroad.
speaker: Narrator

text: When harvest time approached, he sent his servants to the tenant farmers to collect his produce.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the farmers took his servants and beat one, killed another, and attacked another with stones.
speaker: Narrator

text: Again, he sent other servants to them, a greater number than the first, but the tenant farmers treated them the same way.
speaker: Narrator

text: Finally, he sent his son to them, thinking, ‘They will respect my son.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the tenant farmers saw his son, they told one another, ‘This is the heir. Come on, let’s kill him and get his inheritance!’
speaker: Narrator

text: So they grabbed him, threw him out of the vineyard, and killed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when the owner of the vineyard returns, what will he do to those farmers?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They told him, “He will put those horrible men to a horrible death. Then he will lease the vineyard to other farmers who will give him his produce at harvest time.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jesus asked them, “Have you never read in the Scriptures,
‘The stone that the builders rejected
    has become the cornerstone.
This was the Lord’s doing,
    and it is amazing in our eyes.’?
speaker: Narrator

text: That is why I tell you that the kingdom of God will be taken away from you and given to a people who will produce fruit for it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The person who falls over this stone will be broken to pieces, but it will crush anyone on whom it falls.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the high priests and the Pharisees heard his parables, they knew that he was talking about them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Although they wanted to arrest him, they were afraid of the crowds, who considered Jesus to be a prophet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Again Jesus spoke to them in parables. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “The kingdom from heaven may be compared to a king who gave a wedding banquet for his son.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent his servants to call those who had been invited to the wedding, but they refused to come.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he sent other servants after saying, ‘Tell those who have been invited, “Look! I’ve prepared my dinner. My oxen and fattened calves have been slaughtered. Everything is ready. Come to the wedding!”’
speaker: Narrator

text: But they paid no attention to this and went away, one to his farm, another to his business.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest grabbed the king’s servants, treated them brutally, and then killed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king became outraged. He sent his troops, and they destroyed those murderers and burned their city.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then he told his servants, ‘The wedding is ready, but those who were invited were not worthy.
speaker: Narrator

text: So go into the roads leading out of town and invite as many people as you can find to the wedding.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Those servants went out into the streets and brought in everyone they found, evil and good alike, and the wedding hall was packed with guests.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When the king came in to see the guests, he noticed a man there who was not wearing wedding clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: He asked him, ‘Friend, how did you get in here without wedding clothes?’ But the man was speechless.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king told his servants, ‘Tie his hands and feet, and throw him into the darkness outside!’ In that place there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth,
speaker: Narrator

text: because many are invited, but few are chosen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Pharisees went and planned how to trap Jesus in conversation.
speaker: Narrator

text: They sent their disciples to him along with the Herodians. They said, “Teacher, we know that you are sincere and that you teach the way of God truthfully. You don’t favor any individual, because you pay no attention to external appearance.
speaker: Narrator

text: So tell us what you think. Is it lawful to pay taxes to Caesar or not?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Recognizing their wickedness, Jesus asked, “Why are you testing me, you hypocrites?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Show me the coin used for the tax.”
They brought him a denarius.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he asked them, “Whose face and name is this?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
They told him, “Caesar’s.”
So he told them, “Then give back to Caesar the things that are Caesar’s, and to God the things that are God’s.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When they heard this, they were amazed. Then they left him and went away.
speaker: Narrator

text: That same day some Sadducees, who claim there is no resurrection, came to Jesus and asked him,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Teacher, Moses said, ‘If a man dies having no children, his brother must marry the widow and have children for his brother.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there were seven brothers among us. The first one married and died, and since he had no children, he left his widow to his brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: The same thing happened with the second brother, and then the third, and finally with the rest of the brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Finally, the woman died, too.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now in the resurrection, whose wife of the seven will she be, since all of them had married her?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus answered them, “You are mistaken because you don’t know the Scriptures or God’s power,
speaker: Narrator

text: because in the resurrection, people neither marry nor are given in marriage but are like the angels in heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the resurrection from the dead, haven’t you read what was spoken to you by God when he said,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘I am the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob’? He is not the God of the dead, but of the living.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the crowds heard this, they were amazed at his teaching.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Pharisees heard that Jesus had silenced the Sadducees, they met together in the same place.
speaker: Narrator

text: One of them, an expert in the Law, tested him by asking,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Teacher, which is the greatest commandment in the Law?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus told him, “‘You must love the Lord your God with all your heart, with all your soul, and with all your mind.’
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the greatest and most important commandment.
speaker: Narrator

text: The second is exactly like it: ‘You must love your neighbor as yourself.’
speaker: Narrator

text: All the Law and the Prophets depend on these two commandments.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While the Pharisees were still gathered, Jesus asked them,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What do you think about the Messiah? Whose son is he?”
They told him, “David’s.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He asked them, “Then how can David by the Spirit call him ‘Lord’ when he says,
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘The Lord told my Lord,
    “Sit at my right hand,
        until I put your enemies under your feet.”’?
speaker: Narrator

text: If David calls him ‘Lord’, how can he be his son?”
speaker: Narrator

text: No one could answer him at all, and from that day on no one dared to ask him another question.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus told the crowds and his disciples,
speaker: Narrator

text: “The scribes and the Pharisees administer the authority of Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: so do whatever they tell you and follow it, but stop doing what they do, because they don’t do what they say.
speaker: Narrator

text: They tie up burdens that are heavy and unbearable and lay them on people’s shoulders, but they refuse to lift a finger to remove them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “They do everything to be seen by people. They increase the size of their phylacteries and lengthen the tassels of their garments.
speaker: Narrator

text: They love to have the places of honor at festivals, the best seats in the synagogues,
speaker: Narrator

text: to be greeted in the marketplaces, and to be called ‘Rabbi’ by people.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But you are not to be called ‘Rabbi,’ because you have only one teacher, and all of you are brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: And don’t call anyone on earth ‘Father,’ because you have only one Father, the one in heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nor are you to be called ‘Teachers,’ because you have only one teacher, the Messiah!
speaker: Narrator

text: The person who is greatest among you must be your servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever exalts himself will be humbled, and whoever humbles himself will be exalted.
speaker: Narrator

text: “How terrible it will be for you, scribes and Pharisees, you hypocrites! You shut the door to the kingdom from heaven in people’s faces. You don’t go in yourselves, and you don’t allow those who are trying to enter to go in.
speaker: Narrator

text: “How terrible it will be for you, scribes and Pharisees, you hypocrites! You devour widows’ houses and say long prayers to cover it up. Therefore, you will receive greater condemnation!
speaker: Narrator

text: “How terrible it will be for you, scribes and Pharisees, you hypocrites! You travel over land and sea to make a single convert, and when this happens you make him twice as fit for hell as you are.
speaker: Narrator

text: “How terrible it will be for you, blind guides! You say, ‘Whoever swears an oath by the sanctuary is excused, but whoever swears an oath by the gold of the sanctuary must keep his oath.’
speaker: Narrator

text: You blind fools! What is more important, the gold or the sanctuary that made the gold holy?
speaker: Narrator

text: Again you say, ‘Whoever swears an oath by the altar is excused, but whoever swears by the gift that is on it must keep his oath.’
speaker: Narrator

text: You blind men! Which is more important, the gift or the altar that makes the gift holy?
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, the one who swears an oath by the altar swears by it and by everything on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who swears an oath by the sanctuary swears by it and by the one who lives there.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the one who swears an oath by heaven swears by God’s throne and by the one who sits on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “How terrible it will be for you, scribes and Pharisees, you hypocrites! You give a tenth of your mint, dill, and cummin, but have neglected the more important matters of the Law: justice, mercy, and faithfulness. These are the things you should have practiced, without neglecting the others.
speaker: Narrator

text: You blind guides! You filter out a gnat, yet swallow a camel!
speaker: Narrator

text: “How terrible it will be for you, scribes and Pharisees, you hypocrites! You clean the outside of the cup and the plate, but on the inside they are full of greed and self-indulgence.
speaker: Narrator

text: You blind Pharisee! First clean the inside of the cup, so that its outside may also be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: “How terrible it will be for you, scribes and Pharisees, you hypocrites! You are like whitewashed tombs that look beautiful on the outside but inside are full of dead people’s bones and every kind of impurity.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way, on the outside you look righteous to people, but inside you are full of hypocrisy and lawlessness.
speaker: Narrator

text: “How terrible it will be for you, scribes and Pharisees, you hypocrites! You build tombs for the prophets and decorate the monuments of the righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you say, ‘If we had been living in the days of our ancestors, we would have had no part with them in shedding the blood of the prophets.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, you testify against yourselves that you are descendants of those who murdered the prophets.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then finish what your ancestors started!
speaker: Narrator

text: You snakes, you children of serpents! How can you escape being condemned to hell?
speaker: Narrator

text: “That is why I am sending you prophets, wise men, and scribes. Some of them you will kill and crucify, and some of them you will whip in your synagogues and persecute from town to town.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a result, you will be held accountable for all the righteous blood shed on earth, from the blood of the righteous Abel to the blood of Berechiah’s son Zechariah, whom you murdered between the sanctuary and the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: I tell all of you with certainty, all these things will happen to those living today.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “O Jerusalem, Jerusalem, who kills the prophets and stones to death those who have been sent to her! How often I wanted to gather your children together as a hen gathers her chicks under her wings, but you were unwilling!
speaker: Narrator

text: Look! Your house is left abandoned!
speaker: Narrator

text: I tell you, you will not see me again until you say, ‘How blessed is the one who comes in the name of the Lord!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: After Jesus had left the Temple and was walking away, his disciples came up to him to point out to him the Temple buildings.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in reply he responded to them, “You see all these things, don’t you? I tell all of you with certainty, not even a single stone here will be left standing on top of another that won’t be completely demolished.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now while Jesus was sitting on the Mount of Olives, the disciples came to him privately and said, “Tell us, when will these things happen, and what will be the sign of your coming and of the end of the age?”
speaker: Narrator

text: In reply, Jesus told them, “See to it that no one deceives you,
speaker: Narrator

text: because many will come in my name, proclaiming, ‘I’m the Messiah,’ and they will deceive many people.
speaker: Narrator

text: You’ll begin to hear of wars and rumors of wars. See to it that you don’t panic. These things must take place, but the end won’t have come yet,
speaker: Narrator

text: because nation will rise up in arms against nation, and kingdom against kingdom. There will be famines and earthquakes in various places.
speaker: Narrator

text: But all these things are only a beginning of agonies.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then they’ll hand you over to suffer and will kill you, and you’ll be hated by all the nations on account of my name.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then many people will fall away, will betray one another, and will hate one another.
speaker: Narrator

text: Many false prophets will appear and deceive many people,
speaker: Narrator

text: and because lawlessness will increase, the love of many people will grow cold.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the person who endures to the end will be saved.
speaker: Narrator

text: And this gospel of the kingdom will be proclaimed throughout the inhabited world as a testimony to all nations, and then the end will come.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “So when you see the destructive desecration, mentioned by the prophet Daniel, standing in the Holy Place (let the reader take note),
speaker: Narrator

text: then those who are in Judea must flee to the mountains.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who’s on the housetop must not come down to get what is in his house,
speaker: Narrator

text: and anyone who’s in the field must not turn back to get his coat.
speaker: Narrator

text: “How terrible it will be for women who are pregnant or who are nursing babies in those days!
speaker: Narrator

text: Pray that it may not be in winter or on a Sabbath when you flee,
speaker: Narrator

text: because at that time there will be great suffering, the kind that hasn’t happened from the beginning of the world until now and certainly won’t ever happen again.
speaker: Narrator

text: If those days hadn’t been shortened, no one would survive. But for the sake of the elect, those days will be shortened.
speaker: Narrator

text: “At that time, if anyone says to you, ‘Look here! The Messiah!’ or ‘There he is!’, don’t believe it,
speaker: Narrator

text: because false messiahs and false prophets will have arisen and will produce great signs and startling demonstrations so as to deceive, if possible, even the elect.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember, I’ve told you beforehand.
speaker: Narrator

text: So if they say to you, ‘Look! He’s in the wilderness,’ don’t go out looking for him. And if they say, ‘Look! He’s in the storeroom,’ don’t believe it,
speaker: Narrator

text: because just as the lightning comes from the east and flashes as far as the west, so will be the coming of the Son of Man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wherever there’s a corpse, there the vultures will gather.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Now immediately after the troubles of those days,
‘The sun will be darkened,
    the moon will not reflect its light,
the stars will fall from the sky,
    and the powers from the heavens will be disrupted.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the sign that is the Son of Man will appear in the sky, and all ‘the tribes of the land will mourn’ as they see ‘the Son of Man coming on the clouds of heaven’ with power and great glory.
speaker: Narrator

text: He’ll send out his angels with a loud trumpet blast, and they’ll gather his elect from the four winds, from one end of heaven to another.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now learn a lesson from the fig tree. When its branches become tender and it produces leaves, you know that summer is near.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way, when you see all these things, you’ll know that the Son of Man is near, right at the door.
speaker: Narrator

text: I tell all of you with certainty, this generation won’t disappear until these things take place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Heaven and earth will disappear, but my words will never disappear.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “No one knows when that day and hour will come—neither the heavenly angels nor the Son, but only the Father,
speaker: Narrator

text: because just as it was in Noah’s time, so it will be when the Son of Man comes.
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days before the flood, people were eating and drinking, marrying and giving in marriage right up to the day when Noah went into the ark.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were unaware of what was happening until the flood came and swept all of them away. That’s how it will be when the Son of Man appears.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time, two people will be in the field. One will be taken, and one will be left behind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two women will be grinding grain at the mill. One will be taken, and one will be left behind.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So keep on watching, because you don’t know on what day your Lord is coming.
speaker: Narrator

text: But be sure of this: if the owner of the house had known when during the night the thief would be coming, he would have stayed awake and not allowed his house to be broken into.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you, too, must be ready, because the Son of Man will come at an hour you are not expecting.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Who, then, is the faithful and wise servant whom his master has put in charge of his household to give the others their food at the right time?
speaker: Narrator

text: How blessed is that servant whom his master finds doing this when he comes!
speaker: Narrator

text: I tell all of you with certainty, he will put him in charge of all his property.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But if that wicked servant says to himself, ‘My master has been delayed,’
speaker: Narrator

text: and begins to beat his fellow servants and eat and drink with the drunks,
speaker: Narrator

text: that servant’s master will come on a day when he doesn’t expect him and at an hour that he doesn’t know.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then his master will punish him severely and assign him a place with the hypocrites. In that place there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “At that time, the kingdom from heaven will be comparable to ten bridesmaids who took their oil lamps and went out to meet the groom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now five of them were foolish, and five were wise,
speaker: Narrator

text: because when the foolish ones took their lamps, they didn’t take any oil with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the wise ones took flasks of oil with their lamps.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since the groom was late, all of them became sleepy and lay down.
speaker: Narrator

text: But at midnight there came a shout: ‘The groom is here! Come out to meet him!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the bridesmaids woke up and got their lamps ready.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But the foolish ones told the wise, ‘Give us some of your oil, because our lamps are going out!’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But the wise ones replied, ‘No! There will never be enough for us and for you. You’d better go to the dealers and buy some for yourselves.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “While they were away buying it, the groom arrived. Those who were ready went with him into the wedding banquet, and the door was closed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, the other bridesmaids arrived and said, ‘Lord, lord, open up for us!’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But he replied, ‘I tell all of you with certainty, I don’t know you!’
speaker: Narrator

text: So keep on watching, because you don’t know the day or the hour.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Similarly, it is like a man going on a trip, who called his servants and turned his money over to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: To one man he gave five talents, to another two, and to another one, based on their ability. Then he went on his trip.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The one who received five talents went out at once and invested them and earned five more.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way, the one who had two talents earned two more.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the one who received one talent went off, dug a hole in the ground, and buried his master’s money.
speaker: Narrator

text: “After a long time, the master of those servants returned and settled accounts with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who had received five talents came up and brought five more talents. ‘Master,’ he said, ‘you gave me five talents. See, I’ve earned five more talents.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “His master told him, ‘Well done, good and trustworthy servant! Since you’ve been trustworthy with a small amount, I’ll put you in charge of a large amount. Come and share your master’s joy!’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The one with two talents also came forward and said, ‘Master, you gave me two talents. See, I’ve earned two more talents.
speaker: Narrator

text: “His master told him, ‘Well done, good and trustworthy servant! Since you’ve been trustworthy with a small amount, I’ll put you in charge of a large amount. Come and share your master’s joy!’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then the one who had received one talent came forward and said, ‘Master, I knew that you were a hard man, harvesting where you haven’t planted and gathering where you haven’t scattered any seed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since I was afraid, I went off and hid your talent in the ground. Here, take what’s yours!’
speaker: Narrator

text: “His master answered him, ‘You evil and lazy servant! So you knew that I harvested where I haven’t planted and gathered where I haven’t scattered any seed?
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you should’ve invested my money with the bankers. When I returned, I would’ve received my money back with interest.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the master said, ‘Take the talent from him and give it to the man who has the ten talents,
speaker: Narrator

text: because to everyone who has something, more will be given, and he’ll have more than enough. But from the person who has nothing, even what he has will be taken away from him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Throw this useless servant into the darkness outside! In that place there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “When the Son of Man comes in his glory and all the angels are with him, he will sit on his glorious throne.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the nations will be assembled in front of him, and he will cull them out, one from another, like a shepherd separates sheep from goats.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will put the sheep on his right but the goats on his left.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then the king will say to those on his right, ‘Come, you who have been blessed by my Father! Inherit the kingdom prepared for you from the foundation of the world,
speaker: Narrator

text: because I was hungry, and you gave me something to eat. I was thirsty, and you gave me something to drink. I was a stranger, and you welcomed me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was naked, and you clothed me. I was sick, and you took care of me. I was in prison, and you visited me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then the righteous will say to him, ‘Lord, when did we see you hungry and give you something to eat, or thirsty and give you something to drink?
speaker: Narrator

text: When did we see you as a stranger and welcome you, or see you naked and clothe you?
speaker: Narrator

text: When did we see you sick or in prison, and visit you?’
speaker: Narrator

text: The king will answer them, ‘I tell all of you with certainty, since you did it for one of the least important of these brothers of mine, you did it for me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then he will say to those on his left, ‘Get away from me, you who are accursed, into the eternal fire that has been prepared for the Devil and his angels!
speaker: Narrator

text: Here’s why: I was hungry, and you gave me nothing to eat. I was thirsty, and you gave me nothing to drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was a stranger, and you didn’t welcome me. I was naked, and you didn’t clothe me. I was sick and in prison, and you didn’t visit me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then they will reply, ‘Lord, when did we see you hungry or thirsty or as a stranger or naked or sick or in prison and didn’t help you?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he will say to them, ‘I tell all of you with certainty, since you didn’t do it for one of the least important of these, you didn’t do it for me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: These people will go away into eternal punishment, but the righteous will go into eternal life.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus had finished saying all these things, he told his disciples,
speaker: Narrator

text: “You know that the Passover will take place in two days, and the Son of Man will be handed over to be crucified.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the high priests and the elders of the people assembled in the courtyard of the high priest, who was named Caiaphas.
speaker: Narrator

text: They conspired to arrest Jesus by treachery and to kill him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they kept saying, “This must not happen during the festival. Otherwise, there’ll be a riot among the people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While Jesus was in Bethany at the home of Simon the leper,
speaker: Narrator

text: a woman came to him with an alabaster jar of very expensive perfume and poured it on his head while he sat at the table.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the disciples saw this, they became irritated and said, “Why this waste?
speaker: Narrator

text: Surely this perfume could’ve been sold for a high price and the money given to the destitute.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But knowing this, Jesus asked them, “Why are you bothering the woman? She has done a beautiful thing for me.
speaker: Narrator

text: You’ll always have the destitute with you, but you’ll not always have me.
speaker: Narrator

text: When she poured this perfume on my body, she was preparing me for burial.
speaker: Narrator

text: I tell all of you with certainty, wherever this gospel is proclaimed throughout the whole world, what she has done will also be told as a memorial to her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then one of the Twelve, who was called Judas Iscariot, went to the high priests
speaker: Narrator

text: and inquired, “What are you willing to give me if I betray Jesus to you?” They offered him 30 pieces of silver,
speaker: Narrator

text: and from then on he began to look for an opportunity to betray Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the first day of the Festival of Unleavened Bread, the disciples approached Jesus and asked, “Where do you want us to make preparations for you to eat the Passover meal?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Go to a certain man in the city and say to him, ‘The Teacher says, “My time is near. I will celebrate the Passover with my disciples at your house.”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the disciples did as Jesus had directed them, and they prepared the Passover meal.
speaker: Narrator

text: When evening came, Jesus was sitting at the table with the Twelve.
speaker: Narrator

text: While they were eating, he said, “I tell all of you with certainty, one of you is going to betray me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Feeling deeply distressed, each one began to ask him, “Surely I am not the one, Lord?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He replied, “The man who has dipped his hand into the bowl with me will betray me.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Son of Man is going away, just as it has been written about him. How terrible it will be for that man by whom the Son of Man is betrayed! It would have been better for him if he had never been born.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Judas, who was going to betray him, asked, “Rabbi, I’m not the one, am I?”
Jesus told him, “You have said so.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While they were eating, Jesus took a loaf of bread and blessed it. Then he broke it in pieces and handed it to the disciples, saying, “Take this and eat it. This is my body.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he took a cup, gave thanks, and gave it to them, saying, “Drink from it, all of you,
speaker: Narrator

text: because this is my blood of the new covenant that is being poured out for many people for the forgiveness of sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: I tell all of you I will never again drink the product of the vine until that day when I drink it with you once again in my Father’s kingdom.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After singing a hymn, they went out to the Mount of Olives.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Jesus told them, “All of you will turn against me this very night, because it is written,
‘I will strike the shepherd,
    and the sheep of the flock will be scattered.’
speaker: Narrator

text: However, after I have been raised, I will go to Galilee ahead of you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Peter told him, “Even if everyone else turns against you, I certainly won’t!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus told him, “I tell you with certainty, before a rooster crows this very night, you will deny me three times.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Peter told him, “Even if I have to die with you, I will never deny you!” And all the disciples said the same thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus went with them to a place called Gethsemane. He told the disciples, “Sit down here while I go over there and pray.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Taking Peter and the two sons of Zebedee with him, he began to be grieved and troubled.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he told them, “I’m so deeply grieved that I feel I’m about to die. Wait here and stay awake with me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Going on a little farther, he fell on his face and prayed, “O my Father, if it is possible, let this cup pass from me. Yet not what I want but what you want.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he went back to the disciples, he found them asleep. He told Peter, “So, you men couldn’t stay awake with me for one hour, could you?
speaker: Narrator

text: All of you must stay awake and pray that you won’t be tempted. The spirit is indeed willing, but the body is weak.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He went away a second time and prayed, “My Father, if this cup cannot go away unless I drink it, let your will be done.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he came back and found them asleep, because they could not keep their eyes open.
speaker: Narrator

text: After leaving them again, he went away and prayed again for the third time, saying the same thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he came back to the disciples and told them, “You might as well keep on sleeping and resting. Look! The time is near for the Son of Man to be betrayed into the hands of sinners.
speaker: Narrator

text: Get up! Let’s go! See, the one who is betraying me is near!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Just then, while Jesus was still speaking, Judas, one of the Twelve, arrived. A large crowd armed with swords and clubs was with him. They were from the high priests and elders of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the betrayer personally had given them a signal, saying, “The one I kiss is the man. Arrest him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Judas immediately went up to Jesus and said, “Hello, Rabbi!” and kissed him tenderly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus asked him, “Friend, why are you here?” Then the other men surged forward, took hold of Jesus, and arrested him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Suddenly, one of the men with Jesus reached out his hand, drew his sword, and struck the high priest’s servant, cutting off his ear.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus told him, “Put your sword back in its place! Everyone who uses a sword will be killed by a sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t you think that I could call on my Father, and he would send me more than twelve legions of angels now?
speaker: Narrator

text: How, then, would the Scriptures be fulfilled that say this must happen?”
speaker: Narrator

text: At this point, Jesus asked the crowds, “Have you come out with swords and clubs to arrest me as if I were a bandit? Day after day I sat teaching in the Temple, yet you didn’t arrest me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But all of this has happened so that the writings of the prophets might be fulfilled.”
Then all the disciples deserted Jesus and ran away.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who had arrested Jesus took him to Caiaphas, the high priest, where the scribes and the elders had assembled.
speaker: Narrator

text: Peter, however, followed him at a distance as far as the high priest’s courtyard. He went inside and sat down with the servants to see how this would end.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, the high priests and the whole Council were looking for false testimony against Jesus in order to have him put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they couldn’t find any, even though many false witnesses had come forward. At last two men came forward
speaker: Narrator

text: and stated, “This man said, ‘I can destroy the sanctuary of God and rebuild it in three days.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: At this, the high priest stood up and asked Jesus, “Don’t you have any answer to what these men are testifying against you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jesus was silent. Then the high priest told him, “I command you by the living God to tell us if you are the Messiah, the Son of God!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus told him, “You have said so. Nevertheless I tell you, from now on you will see ‘the Son of Man seated at the right hand of Power’ and ‘coming on the clouds of heaven.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the high priest tore his robes and said, “He has blasphemed! Why do we still need witnesses? Listen! You yourselves have just heard the blasphemy!
speaker: Narrator

text:
What is your verdict?”
They replied, “He deserves to die!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they spit in his face and hit him. Some slapped him,
speaker: Narrator

text: saying, “Prophesy to us, you Messiah! Who hit you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Peter was sitting outside in the courtyard when a servant girl came up to him and said, “You, too, were with Jesus the Galilean.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he denied it in front of them all. “I don’t know what you’re talking about!” he exclaimed.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he went out to the gateway, another woman saw him and told those who were there, “This man was with Jesus from Nazareth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Again he denied it and swore with an oath, “I don’t know the man!”
speaker: Narrator

text: After a little while, the people who were standing there came up and told Peter, “Obviously you’re also one of them, because your accent gives you away.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he began to curse violently. “I don’t know the man!” he swore solemnly. Just then a rooster crowed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Peter remembered the words of Jesus when he said, “Before a rooster crows, you’ll deny me three times.” Then he went outside and cried bitterly.
speaker: Narrator

text: When morning came, all the high priests and elders of the people conspired against Jesus to put him to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: They bound him with chains, led him away, and handed him over to Pontius Pilate, the governor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Judas, who had betrayed him, regretted what had happened when he saw that Jesus was condemned. He brought the 30 pieces of silver back to the high priests and elders,
speaker: Narrator

text:
saying, “I have sinned by betraying innocent blood.”
But they replied, “What do we care? Attend to that yourself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he flung the pieces of silver into the sanctuary, went outside, ran away, and hanged himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: The high priests picked up the pieces of silver and said, “It is not lawful to put this into the Temple treasury, because it is blood money.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they decided to use the money to buy the Potter’s Field as a burial ground for foreigners.
speaker: Narrator

text: That is why that field has been called the Field of Blood to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then what had been declared through the prophet Jeremiah was fulfilled when he said,
“They took the 30 pieces of silver,
    the value of the man on whom a price had been set by the Israelis,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and they gave them for the potter’s field,
    as the Lord commanded me.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Meanwhile, Jesus was made to stand in front of the governor. The governor asked him, “Are you the king of the Jews?”
Jesus said, “You say so.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While Jesus was being accused by the high priests and elders, he made no reply.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pilate asked him, “Don’t you hear how many charges they’re bringing against you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jesus did not reply at all, so that the governor was very surprised.
speaker: Narrator

text: At every festival the governor had a custom of releasing to the crowd any prisoner whom they wanted.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time they were holding a notorious prisoner named Barabbas.
speaker: Narrator

text: So when the people had gathered, Pilate asked them, “Which man do you want me to release for you—Barabbas, or Jesus who is called ‘the Messiah’?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He did this because he knew that they had handed him over out of jealousy.
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was sitting on the judge’s seat, his wife sent him a message that said, “Have nothing to do with that righteous man, because today I have suffered terribly due to a dream I had about him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the high priests and elders persuaded the crowds to ask for Barabbas and to demand that Jesus be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the governor asked them, “Which of the two men do you want me to release for you?”
“Barabbas!” they replied.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pilate asked them, “Then what should I do with Jesus, who is called the Messiah?”
They all said, “Let him be crucified!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He asked, “What has he done wrong?”
But they kept shouting louder and louder, “Let him be crucified!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Pilate saw that he was getting nowhere, but that a riot was about to break out instead. So he took some water and washed his hands in front of the crowd, saying, “I am innocent of this man’s blood. Attend to that yourselves.”
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people answered, “Let his blood be on us and our children!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he released Barabbas for them, but he had Jesus whipped and handed over to be crucified.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the governor’s soldiers took Jesus into the imperial headquarters and gathered the whole company of soldiers around him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They stripped him and put a scarlet robe on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Twisting some thorns into a victor’s crown, they placed it on his head and put a stick in his right hand. They knelt down in front of him and began making fun of him, saying, “Long live the king of the Jews!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they spit on him and took the stick and hit him repeatedly on his head.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they had finished making fun of him, they stripped him of the robe, put his own clothes back on him, and led him away to crucify him.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they were leaving, they found a man from Cyrene named Simon, whom they forced to carry Jesus’ cross.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came to a place called Golgotha (which means “Skull Place”),
speaker: Narrator

text: they offered him a drink of wine mixed with gall. But when he tasted it, he refused to drink it.
speaker: Narrator

text: After they had crucified him, they determined who would get his clothes by throwing dice for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they sat down there and continued guarding him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Above his head they placed the charge against him. It read, “This is Jesus, the king of the Jews.”
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time two bandits were crucified with him, one on his right and the other on his left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who passed by kept insulting him, shaking their heads,
speaker: Narrator

text: and saying, “You who were going to destroy the sanctuary and rebuild it in three days—save yourself! If you’re the Son of God, come down from the cross!”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way the high priests, along with the scribes and elders, were also making fun of him. They kept saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “He saved others but can’t save himself! He is the king of Israel. Let him come down from the cross now, and we will believe in him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He trusts in God. Let God rescue him, if he wants to do so now. After all, he said, ‘I am the Son of God.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: In a similar way, the bandits who were being crucified with him kept insulting him.
speaker: Narrator

text: From noon on, darkness came over the whole land until three in the afternoon.
speaker: Narrator

text: About three o’clock, Jesus cried out with a loud voice, “Eli, eli, lema sabachthani?”, which means, “My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: When some of the people standing there heard this, they said, “He’s calling for Elijah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So one of the men ran off at once, took a sponge, and soaked it in some sour wine. Then he put it on a stick and offered Jesus a drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the others kept saying, “Wait! Let’s see if Elijah will come and save him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus cried out with a loud voice again and died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Suddenly, the curtain in the sanctuary was torn in two from top to bottom, the earth shook, rocks were split open,
speaker: Narrator

text: tombs were opened, and many saints who had died were brought back to life.
speaker: Narrator

text: After his resurrection, they came out of their tombs, went into the Holy City, and appeared to many people.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the centurion and those guarding Jesus with him saw the earthquake and the other things that were taking place, they were terrified and said, “This man certainly was the Son of God!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now many women were also there, watching from a distance. They had accompanied Jesus from Galilee and had ministered to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Among them were Mary Magdalene, Mary the mother of James and Joseph, and the mother of Zebedee’s sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later that evening, a rich man arrived from Arimathea. His name was Joseph, and he had become a disciple of Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went to Pilate and asked for the body of Jesus, and Pilate ordered it to be done.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joseph took the body and wrapped it in a clean linen cloth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he placed it in his own new tomb, which he had cut out of the rock. After rolling a large stone across the door of the tomb, he left,
speaker: Narrator

text: but Mary Magdalene and the other Mary remained there, sitting in front of the tomb.
speaker: Narrator

text: The following day (that is, after the Day of Preparation), the high priests and Pharisees gathered before Pilate
speaker: Narrator

text: and said, “Sir, we remember how that impostor said while he was still alive, ‘I will be raised after three days.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, order the tomb to be secured until the third day, or his disciples may go and steal him and then tell the people, ‘He has been raised from the dead.’ Then the last deception would be worse than the first one.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Pilate told them, “You have a military guard. Go and make the tomb as secure as you know how.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they went and secured the tomb by putting a seal on the stone in the presence of the guards.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the Sabbaths, around dawn on the first day of the week, Mary Magdalene and the other Mary went to take a look at the burial site.
speaker: Narrator

text: Suddenly, there was a powerful earthquake, because an angel of the Lord had come down from heaven, approached the stone, rolled it away, and was sitting on top of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: His appearance was bright as lightning, and his clothes were white as snow.
speaker: Narrator

text: Trembling from fear, even the guards themselves became catatonic.
speaker: Narrator

text: Responding to the women, the angel said, “Stop being frightened! I know you’re looking for Jesus, who was crucified.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is not here. He has been raised, just as he said. Come and see the place where he was lying.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then go quickly and tell his disciples that he is risen from the dead. He is going ahead of you into Galilee, and you will see him there. Remember, I have told you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they quickly left the tomb, terrified but also ecstatic, and ran to tell Jesus’ disciples.
speaker: Narrator

text: Suddenly, Jesus met them and said, “Greetings!” They went up to him, took hold of his feet, and worshipped him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus told them, “Stop being frightened! Go and tell my brothers to leave for Galilee, and they will see me there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While the women were on their way, some of the guards went into the city and told the high priests everything that had happened.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they met with the elders and agreed on a plan to give the soldiers a large amount of money.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “Say that Jesus’ disciples came at night and stole him while you were sleeping.
speaker: Narrator

text: If this is reported to the governor, we’ll personally persuade him to keep you out of trouble.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the soldiers took the money, did as they were instructed, and this story has been spread among the Jews to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The eleven disciples went into Galilee to the hillside to which Jesus had directed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they saw him, they worshipped him, though some had doubts.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus approached them and told them, “All authority in heaven and on earth has been given to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, as you go, disciple people in all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father, and the Son, and the Holy Spirit,
speaker: Narrator

text: teaching them to obey everything that I’ve commanded you. And remember, I am with you each and every day until the end of the age.”
speaker: Narrator
